@Iamadam wrote:

Hah.
It really depends what you want ada. If you don’t need the frame to be resizable, just use a good old null layout. That will allow you to set the bounds of each individual component.
If you want to take a more ‘professional’ approach, use a GridBagLayout or something similar.

item.title: How to make settings dialog boxes
item.dc:creator: @ada ada
item.description:
@ada wrote:

This is what I have done so far:

[code=java]
private static JDialog settingsDialog;
private static JTextField serverName;
private static JSpinner maxUsers;
private static JCheckBox allowNewUsers;
private static JCheckBox logoutIdleUsers;
private static JCheckBox logConsole;
private static JCheckBox logChat;
private static JButton[][] logButtons;
private static JCheckBox enableReportAbuse;
private static JCheckBox logDateAndTime;
private static JComboBox itemCommandMinimum;
private static JComboBox teleCommandMinimum;
private static JComboBox statsCommandMinimum;
private static JComboBox rightClickStatsMinimum;
private static JCheckBox localConnectionsOnly;
private static JComboBox loginMinimum;
private static JComboBox defaultUserRights;
private static JButton changeServerPassword;
private static JCheckBox autoLock;
private static JSpinner maxConnectionAttempts;
private static JSpinner connectionCounterResetInterval;
private static JCheckBox enurClientOnly;
private static JButton[] dialogButtons;

static {
    initialize();
}
private static void initialize()
{
    settingsDialog = new JDialog(CommandWindow.frame, "EnurScape Settings");
    settingsDialog.setLayout(new BorderLayout());
    settingsDialog.setIconImage(CommandWindow.frame.getIconImage());
    JTabbedPane tabbedPane = new JTabbedPane();
    tabbedPane.setUI(new javax.swing.plaf.basic.BasicTabbedPaneUI());
    final String tabNames[] = new String[]{"Server", "Client", "Security", "Other"}; //These are the tab names
    JPanel tabs[] = new JPanel[tabNames.length]; //tabPanels
    final String sectionNames[][] = new String[][]{{"Basic Settings", "Logging"}, {"Command Access", "Client Security", "Default User Rights"}, {"DOS Prevention", "EnurScape Client Only"}, {"About EnurScape Private Server", "Bugs & Suggestions"}}; //These strings are what the titled borders are called
    JPanel sections[][] = new JPanel[tabs.length][3]; //These panels go into the tab panels to create a section with a titled border from the above string array
    for (int i = 0; i < tabs.length; i++) {
        tabs[i] = new JPanel();
        //tabs[i].setLayout(new GridLayout(sectionNames[i].length, 1));
        tabbedPane.addTab(tabNames[i], tabs[i]);
    }
    for (int i = 0; i < sections.length; i++) {
        for (int j = 0; j < sections[i].length; j++) {
            if (sectionNames[i].length <= j) sections[i][j] = null;
            else {
                sections[i][j] = new JPanel();
                sections[i][j].setLayout(new FlowLayout());
                sections[i][j].setBorder(BorderFactory.createTitledBorder(sectionNames[i][j])); // <---- This is where I create the section borders
                tabs[i].add(sections[i][j]);
            }
        }
    }
}

}[/code]

item.title: How to make settings dialog boxes
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

A JDialog for the contents of each tabbed pane? You’d want to use a JPanel instead.

So basically, just design any jpanel the way you normally would to add it to a frame. Use any layout manager you’d like, really (or none if you prefer).

JTabbedPane tabbedPane = nee JTabbedPane();

JPanel somePanel = new JPanel();
// ... Do whatever with the panel

tabbedPane.addTab("Tab Title", somePanel);
